Award.AwardTitle: Membrane Dynamics Underlying Kv2.1 Cluster Formation
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project the PIs will study the regulation of Kv2.1 channel clusters that may play several important biological roles in the brain. Currently, the mechanism by which clusters Kv2.1 are regulated and maintained is unknown. The project focuses on the biophysics of Kv2.1 voltage-gated K+ channel cell surface dynamics with particular emphasis on cytoskeleton-membrane interactions in live cells. The overall goal of the research is to improve our understanding of the mechanism by which the cortical cytoskeleton functionally forms a diffusion limiting fence that selectively corrals a sub-population of Kv2.1 channels. The specific research aims are: (1) characterize the dynamics of clustered and non-clustered channels within various surface regions of cultured neurons, (2) measure the influence of the cortical cytoskeleton and raft microdomains on Kv2.1 channel dynamics, (3) build a microscope to implement high-speed particle tracking and optical tweezers, and (4) determine the mechanism that forms Kv2.1 clusters on the cell surface. This experimental work will lead to unique insights in the molecular mechanism of membrane protein dynamics. The project focuses on investigating Kv2.1 clustering regulation, dynamics and interactions with the cytoskeleton which may lead to improved treatments for acute ischemic stroke through enhanced neuro-protective approaches. The research program will be integrated with an educational component by building an optical tweezers setup for educational purposes. Under-represented students will be recruited at minority meetings and through a Women & Minorities in Engineering Program at Colorado State University.

The project is jointly sponsored by the Physics and the Molecular Cell Biology Divisions at NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The ion channel Kv2.1 is one of the most widespread in the body. Many different mammalian cell types produce Kv2.1 channels including nerve, pancreas, retina, lung and heart cells among others.  In certain tissues, Kv2.1 is known to localize to cell surface domains and the disruption of these domains in the brain is induced by stimuli associated with injury such as trauma and stroke. Figure 1 shows an image of the Kv2.1 cell surface domains on the surface of a live cell. Nevertheless, the clustered channels do not conduct electrical currents and thus the cluster function is not related to traditional ion channel functions.

We have discovered two new Kv2.1 functions in hippocampal neurons: 1) Kv2.1 clusters are trafficking hubs for membrane protein delivery and retrieval at the cell surface. 2) Kv2.1 controls the formation of stable large junctions between the endoplasmic reticulum and the membrane of the cell that have a central role in cell physiology. The results obtained in this project indicate that these surface structures form a new type of organelle involved in cell structure and protein trafficking with potential roles in neurological diseases. In addition these structures could function as signaling stations for the transfer of information from the cell surface to internal structures.

This research was performed using advanced microscopy tools where the behaviors of different molecules within live cells are observed at the individual level. That is, we studied one molecule at a time, obtaining a detailed census of the localization of individual Kv2.1 channels on the cell membrane and investigated their dynamics and interactions in real time. In Figure 2, we observe the trajectory of individual ion channels as they perform an apparently random walk on the cell surface. Detailed analysis of this motion revealed intricate interactions with cellular structures. For example, channels are captured by complexes (clathrin-coated pits, seen as green spots in Figure 2) that attempt to internalize them. The structures that interact with the ion channels are one of the key players in cell signaling pathways by being responsible for recognizing molecules on the surface and transporting them to specific regions within the cell. These studies involved optical imaging with few-nanometer resolution, a technology that seemed unimaginable a few years ago.  Our studies shed light on the complexity by which the living cell employs dynamic interactions in order to organize and compartmentalize structures with different functions.
